title: Should the 'Defund' movement be expanded to large corporations such as Amazon and Google? Why stop at defunding the police? - Quora

response.answer_text: You obviously don’t understand this dumb “defund” movement to begin with. Defunding any police department is a huge mistake and will leave the vulnerable population of every town and city where this takes place, in dire straits. Look at what happened in Seattle, when idiots took over a section of town. People died, people were shot, the leader (supposedly non violent) carried a gun to a meeting with a reporter, claiming that he doesn’t know who to trust. Yea right. You can’t defund something that doesn’t belong to you, nimrod. Google, Amazon, Yahoo, Microsoft, Ebay, Etsy, you name it, they don’t belong to the government, so what is it you wanted to defund? Amazon makes billions but you’re jealous, don’t buy from them. You hate Google because they’re big business, don’t use them. Same with Yahoo, Microsoft, and all the rest. If you don’t like them, don’t use them. But don’t try to put dumb ideas forth for the rest of us to supposedly follow. Doesn’t work that way. If, on the other hand, someone from this dumb Defund movement wants to have a debate, a conversation, a discussion, then bring it on. Otherwise, it means nothing. It will leave the people NOT INVOLVED IN THIS without protection in cities where they need it most.

Google and Amazon aren’t (completely) taxpayer funded whereas the police are. If you don’t like Google, use another search engine. If you don’t like Amazon, use another website. If police in your area are violent and corrupt, you can try not calling them or talking to them, but you’re still at risk of being harassed, falsely arrested, or otherwise victimized by them. Most people think that corporations shouldn’t get government subsidies, but corporate welfare is very profitable for politicians of all parties because they can be turned into campaign donations. Occasionally politicians come along that fight against such grift, but sadly they are few and far between. It is a hard temptation to resist seeing how much money is at stake.
